head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Plans Bioscience Center

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Pharmaceutical, Biotechnology and Science

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Plans Bioscience Center

body.head.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT); Compiled by George James

abstract.p: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg says city plans to create East River Science Park, bioscience research and development center, on Bellevue Hospital Center campus (S)

block.p: The city plans to create a large bioscience research and development center on the city-owned campus of Bellevue Hospital Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The city has requested proposals from developers to create the East River Science Park, which would encompass about 4.5 acres, with more than 870,000 square feet of floor space for research and development. The park would be between 28th and 29th Streets, First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. New York City has tried to lure biotechnology companies but has lost ground to Boston and the Bay Area of California. Henry Kravis and Russell Carson, co-chairmen of the New York City Investment Fund, would give $10 million toward the project.

The city plans to create a large bioscience research and development center on the city-owned campus of Bellevue Hospital Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The city has requested proposals from developers to create the East River Science Park, which would encompass about 4.5 acres, with more than 870,000 square feet of floor space for research and development. The park would be between 28th and 29th Streets, First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. New York City has tried to lure biotechnology companies but has lost ground to Boston and the Bay Area of California. Henry Kravis and Russell Carson, co-chairmen of the New York City Investment Fund, would give $10 million toward the project.
